title: 112_hr198
content: The "Veterans Dog Training Therapy Act" may be cited as the short title. The Department of Veterans Affairs will implement a pilot program on dog training therapy. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will conduct a pilot program to assess the effectiveness of using service dogs to address post-deployment mental health and post-traumatic stress disorder symptoms in veterans with disabilities. The program will run for five years at three to five VA medical centers, providing training areas for educating veterans in service dog training and handling. The areas will include indoor grooming and training spaces, wheelchair accessibility, and classroom facilities. The pilot program for service dog training and handling will include dedicated indoor spaces for grooming and training, wheelchair accessibility, classroom facilities, office space, equipment storage, outdoor exercise areas, and transportation for field trips. The program will be administered by the Recreation Therapy Service of the Department of Veterans Affairs under the direction of a certified recreational therapist. The Department of Veterans Affairs will oversee a pilot program for service dog training, including a director of service dog training with social services background, certified instructors at each site, selection of dogs from shelters or foster homes, and teaching essential commands to all service dogs in training. The pilot program for service dog training overseen by the Department of Veterans Affairs includes ensuring dogs have proper temperament and health clearances, teaching essential commands to service dogs, providing hands-on training, maximizing therapeutic benefits for veterans, and supplying well-trained service dogs to veterans with disabilities. Veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder or other post-deployment mental health conditions can volunteer for the program. The pilot program overseen by the Department of Veterans Affairs allows veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder or other mental health conditions to volunteer for service dog training. Veterans who have graduated from treatment programs and received certification in service dog training are given preference as instructors. Data collection is conducted to assess the program's effectiveness in reducing stigma associated with post-traumatic stress. The pilot program overseen by the Department of Veterans Affairs aims to determine the effectiveness of assisting veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder through service dog training. Data collection includes assessing improvements in emotional regulation, patience, sense of purpose, community reintegration, relationship skills, and sleep patterns, among other benefits. Reports to Congress are required one year after the program's commencement. The pilot program overseen by the Department of Veterans Affairs aims to assist veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder through service dog training. Reports to Congress will include the number of participants, services provided, and effects on symptoms, family dynamics, insomnia, and pain management. The pilot program overseen by the Department of Veterans Affairs focuses on assisting veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder through service dog training. Reports to Congress will cover physiological markers related to interactions with service dogs, family dynamics, insomnia, pain management, overall well-being, and recommendations for program extension or expansion. The term "service dog training instructor" refers to instructors who directly train veterans in service dog handling.
